message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. This study is a retrospective cohort study because the investigators started with a group of patients who did not have syphilis and followed them over time to determine whether active cocaine use was associated with a higher rate of syphilis. A case-control study would have started with patients who have syphilis and compared them to patients without syphilis. A meta-analysis is a statistical method for combining the results of multiple studies, and a cross-sectional study involves collecting data at a single point in time.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. This study is a retrospective cohort study because the investigators identified a group of patients with a specific exposure (active cocaine use) and then followed them over time to determine if they were more likely to develop a certain outcome (syphilis). It is not a case-control study because the investigators did not start with patients with syphilis and compare them to patients without syphilis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The study design involves identifying a group of patients and following them over time to see if they develop syphilis, which is consistent with a cohort study. It is retrospective because medical records were reviewed. The study is not a case-control study, as it is not comparing patients with and without syphilis. It is not a meta-analysis as it is not a systematic review of multiple studies. It is not a cross-sectional study as it involves following patients over time, rather than examining them at a single point in time.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. This study is a retrospective cohort study because the researchers identified a group of patients (coke users without syphilis) and examined the occurrence of syphilis in that same group over a 6-month period. They are comparing the incidence of syphilis between two groups, one with cocaine use and one without, making it different from a case-control study where patients with the disease (cases) are compared to those without the disease (controls).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. This study design involves identifying a group of patients and examining their medical records to determine if they develop a certain condition over a defined period of time. This is a retrospective cohort study. A case-control study would involve comparing patients with a certain condition to those without it to identify potential risk factors. A meta-analysis would involve combining data from multiple studies to draw conclusions. A cross-sectional study would involve examining a group of patients at a single point in time to gather information about a certain condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. This study design involves identifying a group of patients with a specific exposure (cocaine use) and following them over time to see if they develop a certain outcome (syphilis). This is known as a cohort study, and since it looks back on past data, it is retrospective in nature. Therefore, the correct answer is (D), retrospective cohort study.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. This study involves identifying a group of individuals and following them over time to determine whether they develop a specific outcome, which is characteristic of a retrospective cohort study. The investigators have identified a group of individuals who are active cocaine users and are examining their medical records to determine whether they develop syphilis over a 6-month period. Therefore, the correct answer is (D) Retrospective cohort study.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. This study design involves identifying a group of patients who were active cocaine users (exposure) and comparing their likelihood of developing syphilis over a 6-month period to a group of patients without cocaine use (comparison group). This is a retrospective cohort study.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. This study is a retrospective cohort study, as it looks back at medical records to determine if a group of patients (the cohort) who were active cocaine users were more likely to develop syphilis over a 6-month period. A case-control study typically begins with patients who already have the disease, and compares them to patients without the disease to identify risk factors. A cross-sectional study observes a population at a single point in time, while a meta-analysis is a statistical analysis that combines results from multiple studies.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. This study's design follows a retrospective cohort study because the researchers identified patients without syphilis and tracked them to see if they developed syphilis over time. The study's design does not fit the criteria for a case-control study, meta-analysis, or cross-sectional study.
